prior_works.title: Investigating Causal Relations by Econometric Models and Cross-spectral Methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: MECD’s mask-based event prediction and leave-one-out testing directly follow the Granger causality principle of assessing whether removing a past signal reduces predictive power for a target, adapted here to event-level video reasoning.

prior_works.title: Neural Granger Causality for Nonlinear Time Series
prior_works.authors: Alexander Tank; Ian Covert; Nicholas J. Foti; Ali Shojaie; Emily B. Fox
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work shows how to measure Granger-causal influence with nonlinear neural predictors and sparsity/ablation, informing MECD’s use of a learnable predictor plus masking to quantify causal impact between events.

prior_works.title: Detecting and quantifying causal associations in large nonlinear time series networks (PCMCI)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PCMCI formalizes causal discovery over temporally lagged variables at scale, motivating MECD’s structured search over chronologically distributed video events and its efficiency-minded alternative (mask-based prediction) to conditional testing.

prior_works.title: CLEVRER: Collision Events for Video Representation and Reasoning
prior_works.authors: Kexin Yi; Chuang Gan; Yunzhu Li; Jiajun Wu; Antonio Torralba; Joshua B. Tenenbaum
prior_works.role: Causal video reasoning benchmark and modeling
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CLEVRER introduced causal reasoning and counterfactual queries for videos via event abstractions; MECD generalizes this line from single short events to multi-event, long-horizon causal graph discovery in real videos.

prior_works.title: TVQA: Localized, Compositional Video Question Answering
prior_works.authors: Jie Lei; Licheng Yu; Mohit Bansal; Tamara L. Berg
prior_works.relationship_sentence: TVQA’s setup of aligning long video segments with textual context informs MECD’s formulation that takes visual segments and textual event descriptions, while MECD moves beyond QA to explicit causal-graph discovery.

prior_works.title: Dense-Captioning Events in Videos
prior_works.authors: Ranjay Krishna; Kenji Hata; Frederic Ren; Li Fei-Fei; Juan Carlos Niebles
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By establishing temporally localized event proposals paired with captions, this work underpins MECD’s event-centric interface—taking segmented visual events plus textual descriptions as inputs for causal inference.

prior_works.title: TGIF-QA: Toward Spatio-Temporal Reasoning in Visual Question Answering
prior_works.authors: Yunseok Jang; Yale Song; Youngjae Yu; Youngjin Kim; Gunhee Kim
prior_works.role: Early video QA with temporal reasoning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: TGIF-QA catalyzed temporal reasoning in video QA, highlighting the limits of frame-level QA and motivating MECD’s shift from answering isolated questions to discovering structured multi-event causal relations.

synthesis_narrative:
MECD’s core contribution—discovering structured causal relations among multiple events across long videos—sits at the intersection of causal discovery and video-language reasoning. On the causal side, Granger’s seminal notion of causality as predictive necessity directly inspires MECD’s operational test: mask an upstream event and measure how prediction of a downstream result degrades. Neural Granger extensions show that deep, nonlinear predictors can quantify such influences via learnable representations and ablations, while PCMCI motivates scalable, time-lag-aware causal discovery over many variables—principles MECD adapts to event nodes distributed over video timelines with an efficiency-focused masking strategy rather than exhaustive conditional tests.
On the video reasoning side, CLEVRER established video causal reasoning and counterfactual querying with explicit event abstractions, but within synthetic, single-event, short-horizon settings; MECD extends this to realistic, long videos and multi-event causal graphs explaining a final outcome. Foundational video-language works such as TVQA and TGIF-QA highlighted the mechanics of aligning temporal segments with language and the limitations of QA-only evaluation for deeper reasoning. Dense-Captioning Events in Videos contributed the event-centric paradigm—temporal segments paired with textual descriptions—that MECD adopts as its input representation. Collectively, these lines converge in MECD: a dataset and Granger-inspired framework that elevate video understanding from answering isolated questions to constructing comprehensive, event-level causal diagrams over extended narratives.
